author: HCAndersen
text: A VERY old house stood once in a street with several that were quite new and clean.

author: HCAndersen
text: The date of its erection had been carved on one of the beams, and surrounded by scrolls formed of tulips and hop-tendrils; by this date it could be seen that the old house was nearly three hundred years old.

author: HCAndersen
text: Verses too were written over the windows in old-fashioned letters, and grotesque faces, curiously carved, grinned at you from under the cornices.

author: HCAndersen
text: One story projected a long way over the other, and under the roof ran a leaden gutter, with a dragon's head at the end.

author: HCAndersen
text: The rain was intended to pour out at the dragon's mouth, but it ran out of his body instead, for there was a hole in the gutter.

author: HCAndersen
text: The other houses in the street were new and well built, with large window panes and smooth walls.

author: HCAndersen
text: Any one could see they had nothing to do with the old house.

author: HCAndersen
text: Perhaps they thought, "How long will that heap of rubbish remain here to be a disgrace to the whole street.

author: HCAndersen
text: The parapet projects so far forward that no one can see out of our windows what is going on in that direction.

author: HCAndersen
text: The stairs are as broad as the staircase of a castle, and as steep as if they led to a church-tower.

author: HCAndersen
text: The iron railing looks like the gate of a cemetery, and there are brass knobs upon it.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is really too ridiculous."

author: HCAndersen
text: Opposite to the old house were more nice new houses, which had just the same opinion as their neighbors.

author: HCAndersen
text: At the window of one of them sat a little boy with fresh rosy cheeks, and clear sparkling eyes, who was very fond of the old house, in sunshine or in moonlight.

author: HCAndersen
text: He would sit and look at the wall from which the plaster had in some places fallen off, and fancy all sorts of scenes which had been in former times.

author: HCAndersen
text: How the street must have looked when the houses had all gable roofs, open staircases, and gutters with dragons at the spout.

author: HCAndersen
text: He could even see soldiers walking about with halberds.

author: HCAndersen
text: Certainly it was a very good house to look at for amusement.

author: HCAndersen
text: An old man lived in it, who wore knee-breeches, a coat with large brass buttons, and a wig, which any one could see was a real wig.

author: HCAndersen
text: Every morning an old man came to clean the rooms, and to wait upon him, otherwise the old man in the knee-breeches would have been quite alone in the house.

author: HCAndersen
text: Sometimes he came to one of the windows and looked out; then the little boy nodded to him, and the old man nodded back again, till they became acquainted, and were friends, although they had never spoken to each other; but that was of no consequence.

author: HCAndersen
text: The little boy one day heard his parents say, "The old man opposite is very well off, but is terribly lonely."

author: HCAndersen
text: The next Sunday morning the little boy wrapped something in a piece of paper and took it to the door of the old house, and said to the attendant who waited upon the old man, "Will you please give this from me to the gentleman who lives here; I have two tin soldiers, and this is one of them, and he shall have it, because I know he is terribly lonely."

author: HCAndersen
text: And the old attendant nodded and looked very pleased, and then he carried the tin soldier into the house.

author: HCAndersen
text: Afterwards he was sent over to ask the little boy if he would not like to pay a visit himself.

author: HCAndersen
text: His parents gave him permission, and so it was that he gained admission to the old house.

author: HCAndersen
text: The brassy knobs on the railings shone more brightly than ever, as if they had been polished on account of his visit; and on the door were carved trumpeters standing in tulips, and it seemed as if they were blowing with all their might, their cheeks were so puffed out.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Tanta-ra-ra, the little boy is coming; Tanta-ra-ra, the little boy is coming."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the door opened.

author: HCAndersen
text: All round the hall hung old portraits of knights in armor, and ladies in silk gowns; and the armor rattled, and the silk dresses rustled.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then came a staircase which went up a long way, and then came down a little way and led to a balcony, which was in a very ruinous state.

author: HCAndersen
text: There were large holes and long cracks, out of which grew grass and leaves, indeed the whole balcony, the courtyard, and the walls were so overgrown with green that they looked like a garden.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the balcony stood flower-pots, on which were heads having asses' ears, but the flowers in them grew just as they pleased.

author: HCAndersen
text: In one pot pinks were growing all over the sides, at least the green leaves were shooting forth stalk and stem, and saying as plainly as they could speak, "The air has fanned me, the sun has kissed me, and I am promised a little flower for next Sunday- really for next Sunday."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then they entered a room in which the walls were covered with leather, and the leather had golden flowers stamped upon it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Gilding will fade in damp weather, To endure, there is nothing like leather,"

author: HCAndersen
text: said the walls.

author: HCAndersen
text: Chairs handsomely carved, with elbows on each side, and with very high backs, stood in the room, and as they creaked they seemed to say, "Sit down.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh dear, how I am creaking.

author: HCAndersen
text: I shall certainly have the gout like the old cupboard.

author: HCAndersen
text: Gout in my back, ugh."

author: HCAndersen
text: And then the little boy entered the room where the old man sat.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Thank you for the tin soldier my little friend," said the old man, "and thank you also for coming to see me."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Thanks, thanks," or "Creak, creak," said all the furniture.

author: HCAndersen
text: There was so much that the pieces of furniture stood in each other's way to get a sight of the little boy.

author: HCAndersen
text: On the wall near the centre of the room hung the picture of a beautiful lady, young and gay, dressed in the fashion of the olden times, with powdered hair, and a full, stiff skirt.

author: HCAndersen
text: She said neither "thanks" nor "creak," but she looked down upon the little boy with her mild eyes; and then he said to the old man, "Where did you get that picture?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "From the shop opposite," he replied.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Many portraits hang there that none seem to trouble themselves about.

author: HCAndersen
text: The persons they represent have been dead and buried long since.

author: HCAndersen
text: But I knew this lady many years ago, and she has been dead nearly half a century."

author: HCAndersen
text: Under a glass beneath the picture hung a nosegay of withered flowers, which were no doubt half a century old too, at least they appeared so.

author: HCAndersen
text: And the pendulum of the old clock went to and fro, and the hands turned round; and as time passed on, everything in the room grew older, but no one seemed to notice it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "They say at home," said the little boy, "that you are very lonely."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh," replied the old man, "I have pleasant thoughts of all that has passed, recalled by memory; and now you are come to visit me, and that is very pleasant."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he took from the book-case, a book full of pictures representing long processions of wonderful coaches, such as are never seen at the present time.

author: HCAndersen
text: Soldiers like the knave of clubs, and citizens with waving banners.

author: HCAndersen
text: The tailors had a flag with a pair of scissors supported by two lions, and on the shoemakers' flag there were not boots, but an eagle with two heads, for the shoemakers must have everything arranged so that they can say, "This is a pair."

author: HCAndersen
text: What a picture-book it was; and then the old man went into another room to fetch apples and nuts.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was very pleasant, certainly, to be in that old house.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I cannot endure it," said the tin soldier, who stood on a shelf, "it is so lonely and dull here.

author: HCAndersen
text: I have been accustomed to live in a family, and I cannot get used to this life.

author: HCAndersen
text: I cannot bear it.

author: HCAndersen
text: The whole day is long enough, but the evening is longer.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is not here like it was in your house opposite, when your father and mother talked so cheerfully together, while you and all the dear children made such a delightful noise.

author: HCAndersen
text: No, it is all lonely in the old man's house.

author: HCAndersen
text: Do you think he gets any kisses?

author: HCAndersen
text: Do you think he ever has friendly looks, or a Christmas tree?

author: HCAndersen
text: He will have nothing now but the grave.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, I cannot bear it."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You must not look only on the sorrowful side," said the little boy; "I think everything in this house is beautiful, and all the old pleasant thoughts come back here to pay visits."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah, but I never see any, and I don't know them," said the tin soldier, "and I cannot bear it."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You must bear it," said the little boy.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the old man came back with a pleasant face; and brought with him beautiful preserved fruits, as well as apples and nuts; and the little boy thought no more of the tin soldier.

author: HCAndersen
text: How happy and delighted the little boy was; and after he returned home, and while days and weeks passed, a great deal of nodding took place from one house to the other, and then the little boy went to pay another visit.

author: HCAndersen
text: The carved trumpeters blew "Tanta-ra-ra. There is the little boy.

author: HCAndersen
text: Tanta-ra-ra."

author: HCAndersen
text: The swords and armor on the old knight's pictures rattled.

author: HCAndersen
text: The silk dresses rustled, the leather repeated its rhyme, and the old chairs had the gout in their backs, and cried, "Creak;" it was all exactly like the first time; for in that house, one day and one hour were just like another.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I cannot bear it any longer," said the tin soldier; "I have wept tears of tin, it is so melancholy here.

author: HCAndersen
text: Let me go to the wars, and lose an arm or a leg, that would be some change; I cannot bear it.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now I know what it is to have visits from one's old recollections, and all they bring with them.

author: HCAndersen
text: I have had visits from mine, and you may believe me it is not altogether pleasant.

author: HCAndersen
text: I was very nearly jumping from the shelf.

author: HCAndersen
text: I saw you all in your house opposite, as if you were really present.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was Sunday morning, and you children stood round the table, singing the hymn that you sing every morning.

author: HCAndersen
text: You were standing quietly, with your hands folded, and your father and mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: You were standing quietly, with your hands folded, and your father and mother were looking just as serious, when the door opened, and your little sister Maria, who is not two years old, was brought into the room.

author: HCAndersen
text: You know she always dances when she hears music and singing of any sort; so she began to dance immediately, although she ought not to have done so, but she could not get into the right time because the tune was so slow; so she stood first on one leg and then on the other, and bent her head very low, but it would not suit the music.

author: HCAndersen
text: You all stood looking very grave, although it was very difficult to do so, but I laughed so to myself that I fell down from the table, and got a bruise, which is there still; I know it was not right to laugh.

author: HCAndersen
text: So all this, and everything else that I have seen, keeps running in my head, and these must be the old recollections that bring so many thoughts with them.

author: HCAndersen
text: Tell me whether you still sing on Sundays, and tell me about your little sister Maria, and how my old comrade is, the other tin soldier.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ah, really he must be very happy; I cannot endure this life."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You are given away," said the little boy; "you must stay.

author: HCAndersen
text: Don't you see that?"

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the old man came in, with a box containing many curious things to show him.

author: HCAndersen
text: Rouge-pots, scent-boxes, and old cards, so large and so richly gilded, that none are ever seen like them in these days.

author: HCAndersen
text: And there were smaller boxes to look at, and the piano was opened, and inside the lid were painted landscapes.

author: HCAndersen
text: But when the old man played, the piano sounded quite out of tune.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he looked at the picture he had bought at the broker's, and his eyes sparkled brightly as he nodded at it, and said, "Ah, she could sing that tune."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I will go to the wars!

author: HCAndersen
text: I will go to the wars!" cried the tin soldier as loud as he could, and threw himself down on the floor.

author: HCAndersen
text: Where could he have fallen?

author: HCAndersen
text: The old man searched, and the little boy searched, but he was gone, and could not be found.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I shall find him again," said the old man, but he did not find him.

author: HCAndersen
text: The boards of the floor were open and full of holes.

author: HCAndersen
text: The tin soldier had fallen through a crack between the boards, and lay there now in an open grave.

author: HCAndersen
text: The day went by, and the little boy returned home; the week passed, and many more weeks.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was winter, and the windows were quite frozen, so the little boy was obliged to breathe on the panes, and rub a hole to peep through at the old house.

author: HCAndersen
text: Snow drifts were lying in all the scrolls and on the inscriptions, and the steps were covered with snow as if no one were at home.

author: HCAndersen
text: And indeed nobody was home, for the old man was dead.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the evening, a hearse stopped at the door, and the old man in his coffin was placed in it.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was to be taken to the country to be buried there in his own grave; so they carried him away; no one followed him, for all his friends were dead; and the little boy kissed his hand to the coffin as the hearse moved away with it.

author: HCAndersen
text: A few days after, there was an auction at the old house, and from his window the little boy saw the people carrying away the pictures of old knights and ladies, the flower-pots with the long ears, the old chairs, and the cup-boards.

author: HCAndersen
text: Some were taken one way, some another.

author: HCAndersen
text: Her portrait, which had been bought at the picture dealer's, went back again to his shop, and there it remained, for no one seemed to know her, or to care for the old picture.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the spring; they began to pull the house itself down; people called it complete rubbish.

author: HCAndersen
text: From the street could be seen the room in which the walls were covered with leather, ragged and torn, and the green in the balcony hung straggling over the beams; they pulled it down quickly, for it looked ready to fall, and at last it was cleared away altogether.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What a good riddance," said the neighbors' houses.

author: HCAndersen
text: Very shortly, a fine new house was built farther back from the road; it had lofty windows and smooth walls, but in front, on the spot where the old house really stood, a little garden was planted, and wild vines grew up over the neighboring walls; in front of the garden were large iron railings and a great gate, which looked very stately.

author: HCAndersen
text: People used to stop and peep through the railings.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sparrows assembled in dozens upon the wild vines, and chattered all together as loud as they could, but not about the old house; none of them could remember it, for many years had passed by, so many indeed, that the little boy was now a man, and a really good man too, and his parents were very proud of him.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was just married, and had come, with his young wife, to reside in the new house with the garden in front of it, and now he stood there by her side while she planted a field flower that she thought very pretty.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was planting it herself with her little hands, and pressing down the earth with her fingers.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh dear, what was that?" she exclaimed, as something pricked her.

author: HCAndersen
text: Out of the soft earth something was sticking up.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was- only think!- it was really the tin soldier, the very same which had been lost up in the old man's room, and had been hidden among old wood and rubbish for a long time, till it sunk into the earth, where it must have been for many years.

author: HCAndersen
text: And the young wife wiped the soldier, first with a green leaf, and then with her fine pocket-handkerchief, that smelt of such beautiful perfume.

author: HCAndersen
text: And the tin soldier felt as if he was recovering from a fainting fit.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Let me see him," said the young man, and then he smiled and shook his head, and said, "It can scarcely be the same, but it reminds me of something that happened to one of my tin soldiers when I was a little boy."

author: HCAndersen
text: And then he told his wife about the old house and the old man, and of the tin soldier which he had sent across, because he thought the old man was lonely; and he related the story so clearly that tears came into the eyes of the young wife for the old house and the old man.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is very likely that this is really the same soldier," said she, and I will take care of him, and always remember what you have told me; but some day you must show me the old man's grave."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I don't know where it is," he replied; "no one knows.

author: HCAndersen
text: All his friends are dead; no one took care of him, and I was only a little boy."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, how dreadfully lonely he must have been," said she.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, terribly lonely," cried the tin soldier; "still it is delightful not to be forgotten."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Delightful indeed," cried a voice quite near to them; no one but the tin soldier saw that it came from a rag of the leather which hung in tatters; it had lost all its gilding, and looked like wet earth, but it had an opinion, and it spoke it thus:-

author: HCAndersen
text: "Gilding will fade in damp weather, To endure, there is nothing like leather."

author: HCAndersen
text: But the tin soldier did not believe any such thing.
